posts.name: Ryan Du
posts.cooked:
Hi Yall,

Today while testing our bot, we had an isue with two motors not showing up with CAN . We tested continuity from RoboRio to a wago with a 120 ohm resistor, and it all showed up. However, I was told that continuity doesnt mean that CAN will work. Could someone explain why that is? Also the motors not showing up were and x44 kraken and an x60 kraken. Thanks!

posts.name: Ian McTavish
posts.cooked: There are some simple strategies to use. First, what changed? If they were working before then something changed. If they are being set up for the first time that is a different problem. Isolate one of the devices and use Phoenix Tuner to verify the CAN Id. Do the same with the other. If any two devices have the same id then there is your problem. Use the blink to verify that the motor controller is the one you think it is. Verify the status lights on the motor controllers. Check your wiring. If your CAN wires are longer than they need to be that can pose an issue. With wiring we use latching Molex connectors. We can disconnect devices easily and test CAN adding one device at a time until we identify a device causing issues.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
If you measure the resistance of a CAN bus, it should read as 60 ohms on your meter. (It will be two 120 ohm resistors in parallel.) If you measured only 120 ohms, that means that one of the end-of-run terminating resistors is attached, but you don‚Äôt have continuity to both 120 ohm end-of-run resistors.

Reasons you could have continuity but not connectivity are many, but on initial deployments, the most common is a switching of CAN -H and CAN -L wires [if you switch them, they‚Äôll still be continuous but won‚Äôt work].

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
Do the CAN connection to your motor controllers have the tiny loop of wire on them?   If so they can come unplugged from the controller without breaking the CAN bus. IMG_2608 454√ó602 21.1 KB
